question: Question_07_(c)
statement:
Let $f(x) = x^2 - 6x$ and let \emph{P} be the point (4, -12).

c) Find the slope of the line tangent to the curve \emph{y} =
$f(x)$ at the point (\emph{a}, \emph{a}\textsuperscript{2} -
6\emph{a}).
sols:
First we take the derivative of the function.

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f'(x) = 2x - 6\end{align*}

To find the slope of the tangent line at the point (\emph{a},
\emph{a}\textsuperscript{2} - 6\emph{a}), we simply need to plug the
value \emph{x} = \emph{a} into the derivative. This gives:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f'(a) = 2a - 6\end{align*}

So the slope of the tangent line is \emph{2a - 6}.
hints:
What is the relationship between the derivative of a function at a point
and the tangent line of a function at that point?
